column37: A feature that I backported depended on an additional gem, but that gem required versions of other gems that conflicted with other gems that depended on the same gems. In other words: / / Existing gem "A" depended on gem "C" version x / New gem "B" depended on gem "C" version y
column38: GIT produces a file with both versions of the conflicting merge. I then either determine that one or the other is to be used, or I edit the combined file to reflect both changes. Tower, which is a GUI for GIT, can also show me the two files side-by-side. However, the use of "ours" and "theirs" is confusing.

column37: Some libraries or code syntax demands a higher version of interpreter, and sometimes it cannot be polyfilled. And often times a polyfill will have different behavior -- even ever so slightly -- causing tests to fail in some cases and not others. In that situation, fixing the backport may break the intended use cases.

column37: I wouldn't say “unable” so much as “unwilling”. Fixes can generally be back ported with enough effort, regardless of dependencies (e.g. you can usually inline the dependencies with the necessary fixes). However, the reality of diminishing returns can often make it better to forgo a particular fix if it's too difficult.
